awd_titl_txt: Multilevel Methods for Numerical Modeling with Applications in Hydrogeology
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on the development of new mathematical tools which improve our understanding and application of advanced computational methods. The research explores novel as well as established practical algorithms which are then validated and verified in a variety of hydrogeological scenarios. One major goal of computational mathematics research, in general, is to improve our understanding of numerical algorithms and to make them more efficient and accurate. However, the tasks of improving methods and then applying them are often completed by distinct groups of researchers and have long transfer times between development and application.  Often, the theoretical findings and the heuristic algorithms developed by practitioners follow different trajectories. Indeed, many valuable numerical techniques have been proposed and used by practitioners without much theoretical justification or for a narrow set of problems. Concurrent improvements based on new mathematical insights are often unrelated to practical problems. This research addresses the disparity between the two disciplinary trajectories by reconnecting advanced and abstract mathematical theories with practice.  The project has the potential to impact a wide range of applications, including for example the  simulation of variably saturated flow.

This project is concerned with the development and analysis of adaptive, conservative and monotone discretizations that are extendable to any order for the solution of nonlinear partial differential equations, such as Richards' equation used to simulate variably saturated flow and Biot's model in poroelasticity. Typically, such discretization methods result in large-scale, ill-conditioned linear systems. The efficient solution of such systems, generally non-symmetric and indefinite, is crucial for the performance of overall  numerical simulation as it consumes the larger part of the computing resources.  Part of this project includes the development of a class of efficient and adaptive multilevel solvers capable of generating flexible hierarchies of spaces. Such hierarchies are useful also in filtering and representing sparse data sets, robust with respect to the structure and the type of data: smooth, oscillatory or combinations of the two. In the targeted applications in hydrogeology, the research will be on techniques which efficiently approximate elevation, groundwater head, precipitation, and other relevant hydrogeological spatial data.

por.por_cntn:
The project focuses on the development of new mathematical tools which improve our understanding and application of advanced computational methods. 

The project has made advancement in several key aspects of computational mathematics and its applications. Several of the results are related to methods for assessing and rigorously estimating the errors in numerical modeling. Such problems occur in every model which uses discretisation or compression of data. Among the achievements in the project are: the first efficient and robust with respect to physical parameters,  error estimators for time dependent problems; design of novel numerical methods based on multilevel techniques for accurate estimation of the modeling error;

The research explores novel algorithms which are validated and verified in a variety of practical scenarios. One major goal of computational mathematics research is to improve our understanding of numerical algorithms and to make them more efficient and accurate. The tasks of improving methods, however,  and then applying them are often completed by distinct groups of researchers and have long transfer times between development and application. Often, the theoretical findings and the heuristic algorithms developed by practitioners follow different trajectories. Many valuable numerical techniques have been proposed and used by practitioners without much theoretical justification or for a narrow set of problems. Concurrent improvements based on new mathematical insights are often unrelated to practical problems. This research addresses the disparity between the two disciplinary trajectories by reconnecting advanced and abstract mathematical theories with practice. 

Impact on practical applications is found in the published results on: estimating the abstract energy of a network; (1) the analysis and design of numerical methods respecting physical laws (conservation of mass, momentum, and energy dissipation); (2) the exploration of practical groundwater flow modeling involving human impact; (3) efficient multilevel algebraic solvers for the nonlinear Richards' equation used in groundwater modeling; (4) the indefinite Helmholtz problems with applications in inverse scattering and imaging; and (5) Adaptive algebraic multilevel solvers for graph Laplacians with applications in network modeling.

The project involved participation of PhD students, undergraduate students and a postdoctoral scholar. These junior participants were involved in the research and mastered several state-of-the-art techniques in computational mathematics.

There were 4 PhD dissertations successfully defended by participants in the project, and 2 undergraduate theses. The involvement of the postdoctoral scholar had, and continues to have, a crucial role in all of the reported research work on a posteriori error estimation, adaptive multilevel methods and their application in scientific machine learning. 

The collaborations established with research groups from Tufts University, University of Zaragoza, and University of Oslo on numerical modeling and scientific machine learning led to implementation of the tools and techniques developed in this project in models of groundwater flow and brain tissue modeling.
